required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Fertility in Patients With Untreated Rectosigmoid Endometriosis

brief_summary.textblock: Several studies investigated the reproductive outcomes after surgical treatment of colorectal endometriosis, mainly segmental colorectal resection. Little information is available on the spontaneous fertility of patients with bowel endometriosis. This study aims to evaluate the fertility of patients affected by rectosigmoid endometriosis who did not undergo previous surgical treatment.

primary_outcome.description: Ultrasonographic evidence of intrauterine gestational sac
Complete expulsion or extraction from a woman of a product of fertilization after 22 completed weeks of gestational age, which, after such separation, breathes or shows any other evidence of life

secondary_outcome.measure: Number (%) of patients conceiving spontaneously/by Assisted Reproductive Technology
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after diagnosis of clinical pregnancy

secondary_outcome.measure: Number (%) of patients undergoing vaginal delivery/delivering by cesarean section

intervention.description: Patients did not undergo surgical treatment for endometriosis and medical consultations were done every 6 months from the beginning of the attempts to conceive

study_pop.textblock: Patients with rectosigmoid endometriosis not undergoing surgical treatment

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Desire of conception
- Diagnosis of rectosigmoid endometriosis by transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) and magnetic resonance imaging enema (MR-e)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous surgery for endometriosis
- Diagnosis of hydrosalpinx at imaging
- Previous conception
- Abnormal semen parameters of male partners

reference.citation: Remorgida V, Ferrero S, Fulcheri E, Ragni N, Martin DC. Bowel endometriosis: presentation, diagnosis, and treatment. Obstet Gynecol Surv. 2007 Jul;62(7):461-70. Review.
